1111291585948463109.text: I was TODAY YEARS OLD when I learned that FORTRAN variables were implicitly typed based on their first letter <https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Fortran/Fortran_variables …> and I-N were implicitly integer (others were real/float) and that's why I've been using i,j,k as for-loop counters for my entire life.

Zether (by @benediktbuenz, Dan Bohen et al.) is the first privacy mechanism built specifically for Ethereum, i.e. account-based smart contract platforms.

Hides both sender/recipient and the amount.

No changes to Ethereum required. Practical today. 
https://crypto.stanford.edu/~buenz/papers/zether.pdf …pic.twitter.com/Me6WZKoxWk

Eth1.x comes with four distinct upgrades:

-State rent
-eWASM
-Storage pruning
-Simulation and emulation

1043864970549710853.text:
#Ethereum EVM quirk: there is no way to determine that I'm currently executing within a selfdestructed contract.
Specifically: if I delegatecall some code, it's impossible to know if that code selfdestructed me, and I thus should revert(). 
Would love to be proven wrong.

1110106315559456768.text:
Will you be more inclined to take part in the governance process of a company if you have their gift vouchers (utility tokens) or their shares (securities)?

You'll rarely see people buying burgers from McDonald's pay extra money to participate in a burger survey

1110104902464925699.text: On the other hand, Security tokens' will mostly be held by accredited Investors that will care about the performance of the underlying security and the token price will reflect that. This will incentivize token holders (investors) to take part in the governance process.

1110104210669010945.text: These governance tokens are positioned as utility tokens and mostly held by traders instead of Investors so their price is not really dependent on the performance of the underlying asset. This makes it tough to incentivize token holders (mostly traders) to vote.

1110103319974957056.text:
This low voter turnout includes votes from employees as well. However, I don't think governance tokens or onchain governance is shit.

IMO it's just that people aren't incentivized enough to vote. It costs Gas and more importantly, time to analyze and vote.https://twitter.com/Obstropolos/status/1109452482873360386 …

1083056236474425344.text:
That being said, I personally haven't looked into ProgPOW's implementation and I don't know enough to back/debunk their claims.

Knowing so little about something so critical is scary. I request all cryptographers in the space to audit ProgPOW.

1083054727506481152.text: Given that #Ethereum will soon be shifting to PoS, ASICs require resource to be designed and manufactured, ASICs aren't resellable and the profit margin of mining ProgPOW on an ASIC will be low, It will probably not be worth it to create ASICs for ProgPOW.

1083053326336315394.text:
Neither is #ProgPOW ASIC proof nor is it meant to be.

It is optimized to use all available resources on the latest mass produced GPUs so that the profit difference between mining on an ASIC over a GPU can be minimized.
